prevail.translation[0].definitions[0].de: if a belief, custom, situation etc prevails, it exists among a group of people at a certain time
prevail.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: the economic conditions which prevail in England and Wales
I admired the creativity which prevailed among the young writers.
prevail.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if a person, idea, or principle prevails in a fight, argument etc, they are successful in the end
prevail.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: He considered lying, but then common sense prevailed.
Your inner strength will enable you to prevail over life’s obstacles.
prevail.translation[1].definitions[0].de: if someone or their arguments, views etc prevail, they finally win an argument after a long period of time
prevail.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: The company is hoping to prevail in a court challenge to the water board ruling.
Kimberly-Clark is asking for a ruling that its patent should prevail over the one issued to P&G.
prevail.translation[1].definitions[1].de: if an attitude or belief prevails, it continues to exist in a particular situation
prevail.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Pessimism and gloom have continued to prevail about Britain’s economic expectations.
Slow holiday trading prevailed in the Treasury market yesterday.
the new spirit of caution that now prevails among Japan’s car makers
